report_title: Pet Food and Supply Wholesaling in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2023 currency. Pet food and supply wholesalers have enjoyed climbing revenue as the popularity of owning animals as household companions continues to grow among different demographics. In 2023, the number of pets in the United States will reach 189.6 million. The increase in pet ownership has coincided with a growing tendency to treat pets as members of the family, which has encouraged consumers to buy higher-priced, premium pet food products that are marketed with special benefits, formulas or ingredients. The industry is expected to see total revenue rise at a CAGR of 2.4% to $19.8 billion over the five years to 2023, despite a contraction of 1.7% in 2023.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pet Ownership is on the Rise
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers have been getting married later and later in their lives on average, and many are choosing to adopt a pet to find companionship in the meantime. Veterinary care has also continued to become more advanced, and pet owners can now seek treatment for pets comparable to human care. This has extended the average lifespan of pets in the US, which has translated to a larger number of pets in the nation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Pandemic Produced a Boom in Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Pet ownership spiked in 2020 as many were restricted to their homes for extended periods of time and sought the companionship of a dog or cat. Despite widespread economic turbulence through 2020, disposable income climbed because of strong government support, enabling consumers to splurge on premium and organic pet food products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Industry Landscape Has Changed in Response to Challenges
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Wholesalers have continued to experience significant disruption from the introduction of e-commerce platforms in recent decades, which are better able to skip wholesalers and fill their inventory by going directly to manufacturers. Because of this rising competition, wholesalers in the industry have taken initiatives to maintain revenue and profit, including strategic merger and acquisition activity.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Pets Are Becoming Part of the Family
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Pet humanization describes the shift in attitudes consumers hold towards their pets, viewing them less like an addition to and more like a part of the family. This long-term trend has continued to ramp up over the past five years. Pet "parents" are more concerned with their pets' wellbeing, so they're much more likely to buy premium pet food and supplies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Positive Economic Trends Will Support Spending on Pets
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A rise in pet ownership will lead to higher demand for both discretionary and nondiscretionary products and services, like food, treats and toys. Along with a rise in cats and dogs adoption, an increase in disposable income will enable a greater number of consumers to spend more on toys and food for them.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Wholesaler Bypass Will Continue to Limit Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: An increasingly large portion of demand for pet food and pet supplies will continue to be captured by e-commerce platforms that have been vertically integrated. These platforms have solid relationships with manufacturers and can skip over wholesalers to provide direct-to-consumer sales that cater to their growing preference for convenience.

Wholesalers will benefit from continued strategic acquisitions of companies that can complement and enhance their collective brand's image and product lineups. By diversifying their portfolios into a wide price range of products, wholesalers protect themselves from volatility and can appeal to larger stores.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Premium Pet Foods Will Find Success
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Pet humanization will continue to ramp up over the next five years, and doting pet "parents" will become even more concerned with the nutritional content of the food they feed their cats and dogs. These higher-margin products will support profit for the industry.

industry_definition: This industry includes businesses that purchase products from upstream industries for sale to downstream industries, including retailers, consumers and other wholesalers. Products sold in this industry include wet and dry food for dogs and cats, bird feed, other pet food and treats, food bowls, collars and leashes, litter, cages, travel carriers and other pet supplies and accessories. Companies in this industry may also wholesale pets.
key_trends: Americans have increasingly humanized their pets, making them part of the family. This has led to increased spending on pets, working in concert with increased pet ownership to strengthen demand for pet food.
The rise of e-commerce platforms has undermined the position of wholesalers. The COVID-19 pandemic has only contributed to consumers' reliance on online marketplaces to the detriment of wholesalers.
Federal agencies regulate the international trade of pet food products. State governments also oversee testing and labeling to ensure products are properly made and advertised.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Pet stores purchase large quantities of pet food and supplies to sell to pet owners through their retail outlets. Purchasing from wholesalers enables pet stores, especially smaller establishments, to source a variety of products without establishing a relationship with a multitude of manufacturers.

Large wholesalers sell pet food and supplies to smaller wholesalers that cannot source directly from manufacturers but are able to access smaller markets. Demand from second-party wholesalers has diminished as the general wholesale sector combats demand encroachment from e-commerce platforms.

Supermarkets and grocery stores have benefited from rising demand for pet food and supplies, while continually increasing the variety of product offerings to compete with larger big-box retailers and warehouse clubs. Many grocery stores engage in wholesale trade to provide private-label and discount pet offerings as a means to capture purchases from more price-sensitive consumers.
Nonetheless, this market segment remains vulnerable to encroachment from e-commerce platforms.

tier_1_suppliers: Meat, Beef & Poultry Processing in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Animal Food Production in the US
Toy, Doll & Game Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Pet Grooming & Boarding in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Pet humanization, whereby consumers increasingly treat pets as part of the family, has resulted in greater demand for premium pet foods and products, typically only available through pet stores.

business_locations.location_description: The Great Lakes region accounts for 12% of industry establishments but 27% of the US population.
The Mid-Atlantic region accounts for 15% of industry establishments and 15% of the US population.
The New England region accounts for 5% of industry establishments and 5% of the US population.
The Plains region accounts for 6% of industry establishments and 7% of the US population.
The Rocky Mountains region accounts for 5% of industry establishments and 4% of the US population.
The Southeast region has the highest percentage of establishments at around 30%, while accounting for 19% of the US population.
The Southwest region accounts for 12% of industry establishments and 23% of the US population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA regulates pet foods through the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act FFDCA. Pet food products need to be safe to eat.

regulations_points.regulation_title: UNITED STATES DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE (USDA) AND THE FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION (FTC)
regulations_points.regulation_description: The USDA and FTC regulate the international trade of pet food products. The National Organic Standards Board NOSB of the USDA develops labeling standards for pet food products, while the FTC also has authority over labeling and pet food advertising.

All employing companies are required to abide by the Fair Labor Standards Act, the Employee Free Choice Act and the Americans with Disabilities Act, which mandate labor standards and the right to organize for employees.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The industry is in the decline stage of its life cycle.
The level of industry assistance is low and steady.

Wholesaling requires substantial labor for sales, delivery and inventory management. Potential pet food wholesalers may find it challenging to attract and retain the skilled labor necessary to operate the business.

basis_points.basis_title: Competition from upstream manufacturers and downstream retailers
basis_points.basis_description: Competitors have cut costs by taking care of wholesale-type activities like purchasing and storage in-house, bypassing pet food and supply wholesalers.

E-commerce and direct-to-consumer selling have become the largest threat to wholesalers. E-commerce platforms offer a direct channel to consumers from product manufacturers, cutting out pet food and supply wholesalers.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Pet food wholesaling is highly fragmented. Although the industry encompasses various national corporations, the bulk of industry activity is captured by small-scale, regional operators.
E-commerce promoting direct-to-consumer selling has been a crucial external threat and the largest contributor to industry revenue decline in recent decades.
Larger operators have engaged in various strategic acquisitions to bolster organic sales growth and expand distribution networks into untapped geographic locations.
The industry's high fragmentation heightens price-based competition.
Highly fragmented markets promote new entrants as companies can capture revenue shares through product or consumer specialization.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Comprise the Majority of Spending
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases include a range of pet food and pet supplies including collars, leashes, medication, shampoos, kennels and pet toys, and, for some wholesalers, a range of pets including dogs, cats, birds, fish, small animals and reptiles.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Wholesaling requires substantial labor for sales, delivery and inventory management
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Potential pet food wholesalers may find it challenging to attract and retain the skilled labor necessary to operate the business.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The spread of market segments suggests that there are limited entry points other than those already served by incumbent operators.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Consumers purchase pet food in line with ownership trends, and the number of household pets, particularly cats and dogs, has continued to grow.
Pet food wholesaling has been undercut by direct-to-consumer (DTC) selling through e-commerce platforms.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in an industry with many competitors?
FAQs.answer: Many wholesalers try to stay competitive by offering specialty products.

FAQs.question: How do shifts in consumer preferences like increased health consciousness, digitalization and sustainability affect your business performance?
FAQs.answer: Some wholesalers have adjusted their product offerings to account for growing demand for natural and organic products.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and ability to grow operations?
FAQs.answer: Some companies have conducted merger and acquisition activity to maintain profitability.

FAQs.question: How does your company negotiate favorable purchase costs with upstream suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Larger wholesalers are better able to negotiate prices with suppliers.

FAQs.question: How has your company been able to implement technology into the purchasing process to make the most efficient buying process for customers?
FAQs.answer: Some wholesalers have implemented software to improve the efficiency of their customer interface.

FAQs.question: Does your company currently have an online platform for volume sales or plans to create an e-commerce platform?
FAQs.answer: Online platforms have made it easier for customers to buy directly from wholesalers.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential future changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers must monitor safety standards for pet products because pet food and supply recalls can be highly publicized and damaging for companies.

FAQs.question: What is your company's policy on handling products?
FAQs.answer: While pet food is not as heavily regulated as most other food products, safety is still crucial for handling pet food.

FAQs.question: How does volatility in the value of the dollar affect demand and profit?
FAQs.answer: Increases in the value of the dollar can create greater overseas competition.

FAQs.question: How do your trading profit margins compare to your main competitors?
FAQs.answer: Most wholesalers in this industry have low profit margins.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels? What factors affect demand and stock levels?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers must be able to control stock on hand to reduce the cost of storing excess goods.

FAQs.question: What alliances or relationships does your business have with other companies? How do alliances affect competition?
FAQs.answer: To be successful, wholesalers must have strong relationships with retail markets.

FAQs.question: How do you cater to the needs of consumers? Do you offer a wide range of products and services?
FAQs.answer: Successful wholesalers offer additional services, such as store planning, inventory control and marketing services, which they adjust to suit the needs of individual customers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the number of households in the United States? What do you do during times of increasing household numbers?
FAQs.answer: According to the American Pet Products Association, 68.0% of US households own a pet.

FAQs.question: How will you outfit your business to best take advantage of this rising trend?
FAQs.answer: Projected changes in the number of cats and dogs in US households are a strong indicator of demand for pet food and supplies wholesalers.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the Consumer Confidence Index? What do you do during times of low consumer confidence?
FAQs.answer: When consumer confidence is strong, individuals' perceptions of the US economy and its future prospects will increase their likelihood of purchasing wholesale and retail pet food and supplies.
